features.popup:
Eel River (Main Stem)
~196 miles from Mendocino National Forest to Pacific Ocean
3,684 sq mi watershed — California's 3rd largest
Highest suspended sediment yield of any major river globally
398 miles Wild & Scenic designation (state 1972, federal 1981)
Named for Pacific lamprey — oldest fish species in the river, millions of years of presence
Dam removal pending: PG&E surrendering Potter Valley Project license — demolition could begin ~2028, making the Eel the longest free-flowing river in California

Middle Fork Eel River
70 miles, 753 sq mi — largest tributary by drainage area
Rises in Yolla Bolly Mountains (Trinity County)
Joins mainstem at Dos Rios
Heart of Yuki territory — Round Valley sits between Middle and North Forks
Black Butte River joins east of Covelo

South Fork Eel River
105 miles from Laytonville to Dyerville through ancient redwood forests
689 sq mi drainage — carries the most water (highest rainfall)
No major dams — one of the most pristine large rivers in California
Cahto and Sinkyone homeland

North Fork Eel River
35 miles, entirely in Trinity County
286 sq mi drainage — Wailaki territory
Remote, rugged wilderness

Outlet Creek
Drains from Willits area into the Eel
One of the few coho salmon runs on the mainstem

Ten Mile River
Largest stream in Coast Yuki territory
Empties into Pacific — important salmon run
Record coho return: 5,574 adult CCC coho in 2023-24 — exceeded ESA recovery targets
TNC restoration: floodplain reconnection, large wood structures since 2018
Boundary between Coast Yuki and Northern Pomo

Noyo River (Pomo: Chemli-bida)
41 miles, 113 sq mi watershed — Fort Bragg's drinking water supply
"Noyo" referred to a Pomo village on Pudding Creek, not the river itself
Still flowing — largely undeveloped, classic salmon-steelhead habitat
Skunk Train railroad follows the river from Willits to Fort Bragg
Coho salmon (endangered), chinook, steelhead — all ESA-listed
Trout Unlimited replaced old culverts blocking fish passage (2020)
Exceeded ESA coho recovery targets in 2023-24 season
Listed under Clean Water Act as impaired (sediment, temperature)
Coast Yuki southern boundary / Northern Pomo territory

Big River
41.7 miles, 181 sq mi watershed — empties at Mendocino village
Longest undeveloped estuary in California — brackish water extends 8 mi upstream
Named for giant redwoods that once lined its banks (Arroyo Grande on 1844 Mexican diseño)
Pre-contact: Me-tum'mah (Mitom Pomo / Northern Pomo) territory
Buldam village on north bank near mouth
Coho, chinook, steelhead — all ESA-listed. Record coho returns 2023-24
Beavers restored in mid-20th century — beaver ponds now helping salmon habitat
First sawmill on Mendocino Coast built at mouth (1852)
Northern Pomo territory — boundary with Coast Yuki to the north

Navarro River
~40 miles through Anderson Valley to Pacific at Navarro-by-the-Sea
Still flowing — major coho/chinook/steelhead river
Estuary restoration: $8.3M TNC grant for floodplain reconnection
2024: first coho in Neefus Gulch (N. Fork Navarro tributary) in 70+ years
after TU removed 18-ft earthen dam and restored 1,600 ft stream channel
Northern Pomo / Central Pomo territory

Albion River
Small coastal river south of Mendocino village
Coho, chinook, steelhead habitat — all ESA-listed
Last wooden bridge on Hwy 1 crossed here until 2020
Central Pomo territory

Garcia River
Flows to Pacific near Point Arena
One of last naturally reproducing wild coho populations on southern Pacific Coast
Lost ~95% of historic winter salmon habitat
TNC built 18 enormous log jams in estuary (2022) — first restoration
Record coho returns 2023-24
Manchester-Point Arena Band of Pomo engaged in restoration planning
"There was a time you could walk across the Garcia on the backs of coho salmon"

Usal Creek
Flows to Pacific at Usal Beach — northern boundary of Coast Yuki territory
Now within Sinkyone Wilderness State Park
Conservation Fund owns lands in watershed
Coast Yuki / Sinkyone borderlands

Pudding Creek
Small creek in Fort Bragg — the Pomo village "Noyo" was actually here, not on the Noyo River
Coho salmon life-cycle monitoring station
Northern Pomo territory

Lake Pillsbury — Drowned Upper Eel River
Created by Scott Dam (1922) — blocks the uppermost Eel River
Inundated Huchnom homeland and upper Eel fish habitat
Blocked salmon/steelhead access to ~10% of the entire Eel watershed
PG&E surrendering license — dam removal could begin ~2028
When removed, Eel becomes longest free-flowing river in California

Lost Salmon Habitat — Mendocino Coast
Only 5% of historic winter habitat for salmon remains (NOAA/TNC studies)
Rivers still flow but streams lack old-growth complexity — massive redwoods,
fallen trunks, root balls, woody debris all removed by 150 years of logging
Floodplains disconnected, estuaries simplified, temperatures elevated
Coho salmon: from hundreds of thousands to <1% of historic numbers statewide
Hope: 15,000+ CCC coho returned to Mendocino Coast 2023-24 — record since monitoring began
$14.5M NOAA grant (2023) for large-scale restoration across 5 watersheds
"We can recover this species and heal the rivers from their historic damage" — NOAA

Yuki Proper (Ukomno'om)
"Valley People" — self-name
Round Valley & upper Eel River drainage
8-9 tribal subdivisions, 500+ village sites
Language isolate — unrelated to any known language family
Possibly 10,000+ years in this homeland
"Yuki" is Wintun for "foreigner" or "enemy"

Huchnom ("Outside the Valley")
Yuki subgroup on South Eel River & Potter Valley
Intermediaries between Yuki and Pomo
Participated in Pomo/Cahto ceremonies
Known as "Redwoods" at Round Valley after forced relocation (1869)
Pre-contact pop: ~500 (Kroeber)

Coast Yuki (Ukohtontilka)
"Ocean People" / "People Beside the Big Water"
~50 miles of Mendocino Coast: Noyo River to Usal Creek
11 groups, each with coastal strip extending inland to redwood forests
Separated from interior Yuki by Cahto migration
Diet: salmon, mussels, abalone, surf fish, sea lions (no canoes)
Invented wooden spatula to pry abalone from rocks
Pre-contact: ~500; down to 15-20 by early 1900s

Cahto / Kato (Tlokyhan — "Grass People")
Southernmost Athabaskan speakers on the Pacific Coast
Long Valley, Cahto Valley, upper South Fork Eel River
~50 village sites surrounded by redwood forests
Bordered on 3 sides by Yukian peoples
Most speakers bilingual in Northern Pomo
Name from Pomo word for "lake" — key village: Djilbi
Pre-contact: 500-1,100

Wailaki (Kinist'ee — "The People")
Eel River Athabaskan / Dene speakers
Main Eel south of Kekawaka Creek & North Fork Eel
3 subdivisions: Eel River, North Fork, Pitch Wailaki
~95-100 villages, 19+ tribelets
Arrived in California ~900 AD
Creator god: Katanagai ("Night Traveler")
Pre-contact: ~2,700 Wailaki; Eel River Athabaskans combined: ~10,700+
"Wailaki" is Wintun for "north language"

Ukomno'om villages — Round Valley (Covelo)
Heart of Yuki world. Nearly circular valley on Middle Eel headwaters. Barrett's Pomo name: maca'-kai ("Indian hemp valley"). Supported largest Yuki population — multiple village groups including Chochhanuk, Mameshishmo, U'wit, Hake, Son.

Witukomno'om — Eden Valley
Yuki subdivision in the Sanhedrin Range between Middle and South Eel Rivers. Small valley with distinct dialect. K'ilikuno'm at lower end.

Utitno'm — Forks of Middle & South Eel
Yuki group at the strategic confluence. Controlled access between river drainages.

Sukshultaano'm — North Fork Middle Eel
Yuki group on Hull Creek (Súkshudltatúm = "straight pine"). Northernmost Yuki territory.

Huititno'm — South Fork Middle Eel
Yuki group in the deep canyons east of Round Valley.

Ta'no'm — Main Eel River
Yuki group along the main Eel. 6 known sub-groups: Kichilpitno'm, Kashansichno'm, Pomahanno'm, Mantno'm, Hanchhotno'm, Ulamolno'm.

Huchnom villages — South Eel River
"Outside the Valley" people. South Eel drainage to Potter Valley. Intermediaries between Yuki & Pomo — participated in ceremonies of both. Cremated their dead.

Coast Yuki village cluster — Rockport/Usal area
Northern Coast Yuki territory. Shell-mound dwellers. 11 groups along 50 miles of coast, each with elected headman.

Coast Yuki — Ten Mile River villages
Ten Mile River was the largest stream in Coast Yuki territory. Salmon caught with spears going upstream, scoop nets coming down.

Coast Yuki — Westport/Beall's Landing area
Southern Coast Yuki territory near modern Westport. Summer camps on windy beaches, permanent villages slightly inland in redwood forests.

Djilbi — Principal Cahto village
The village that gave the Cahto their name (from Pomo word for "lake"). Located in Cahto Valley. Self-name: Tlokyhan ("Grass People"). Goddard recorded 50+ Cahto villages.

Cahto villages — Long Valley (Laytonville)
Three valleys of Cahto settlement. Houses: circular pits 2 ft deep, 4 forked posts, bark/earth covering. Rebuilt every two winters. Villages including ka'ibi ("nuts in"), nebō'cēgût ("ground hump on-top"), seLgaitceli'nda ("rock white run-out").

Cahto — Branscomb/Jackson Valley band
Siinkook-kiiyaahaangn ("South Fork Eel River band"). Villages along South Fork Eel near Branscomb. Multiple named sites including Beehshoochinmiî' ("Horseshoe Bend").

Wailaki — Eel River Mainstem villages
Tsennahkenne (Eel River Wailaki). Largest subdivision. Villages on both sides of Eel River from Boulder Creek to Cottonwood Creek. Multiple bands including Bis-kaiyaah, Daadii'schow-kaiyaah.

Wailaki — North Fork band (Bahneko)
North Fork Wailaki. 6 tribelets along the North Fork Eel. Traded obsidian and shells with Pomo, Yuki, and Cahto.

Round Valley — Yuki Homeland & Genocide Site
The Yuki considered this valley their homeland "since time began"
Nearly circular valley on Middle Eel River headwaters
1854: Asbill brothers arrive — kill Yuki, kidnap 35 girls/women to sell as wives
1856: U.S. establishes Nome Cult Farm (later Round Valley Reservation)
1858-59: Brutal winter massacres — 150-170+ killed in targeted raids
1859: Mendocino War — militias kill hundreds, force survivors to reservation
1863: Nome Cult Trail — 461 Concow Maidu force-marched; only 277 survived
Result: From perhaps 10,000-20,000 Yuki to several hundred by 1864
Benjamin Madley (2016): "a clear-cut example of genocide"
E.N. Anderson: "the extermination of the Yuki was a genocidal massacre"

Tc'ih-Léh-Dûñ ("Fish Run Place")
523 acres of old-growth redwood returned to InterTribal Sinkyone Wilderness Council (2022)
200 acres of ancient coast redwoods, 1.5 miles of Anderson Creek
Renamed from "Andersonia West" — "an act of cultural empowerment and Indigenous resilience"
Sinkyone Council: consortium of 10 federally recognized tribes (founded 1986)
Also stewarding 3,845-acre InterTribal Sinkyone Wilderness (since 1997)
Adjacent to 7,250-acre Sinkyone Wilderness State Park
"Our ancestors are still here, they're still around us" — Buffie Schmidt, Sherwood Valley Rancheria
National Geographic July 2022 "We Are Here" cover story

Needle Rock — Sinkyone Wilderness State Park
Northwest corner of Mendocino Coast — gateway to the Lost Coast
Traditional Sinkyone territory
7,250-acre park — site of original activism that led to Sinkyone Council founding (1986)
Co-founder Priscilla Hunter (Coyote Valley Pomo) championed return of 4,531+ acres
She "journeyed home to her ancestors" November 2024

Spyrock Road Petroglyphs (CA-MEN-1912)
Discovered 1982 beside Spy Rock Road, near Eel River
First evidence of complex rock art boulders in the western United States
Wailaki/Yuki borderlands territory
Bay Area Rock Art Archive field trips documented 1998
Spyrock named for a 540-ft landmark hill east of the Eel River

Bell Springs Petroglyphs (CA-MEN-0433)
Bell Springs area, Eel River region
Documented in Bay Area Rock Art Archive field trips (1998)
Wailaki territory — borderlands with Yuki

Slakaiya Rock (CA-TRI-1)
The most significant petroglyph site in the Eel River region
East bank of Main Fork Eel River, deep canyon, ~520 ft elevation
Site: 105 × 55 m, oak-woodland on stream terrace with schist boulders
3 housepits (~3m diameter, 60cm deep), midden, abundant lithics
Two rock art panels with 6 discrete styles:
• Panel 1: 253 cm × 150 cm on vertical schist face, partly in rock shelter
  SR Style 4: Pecked abstract curvilinear — zigzags, circles, linked circles,
  linked diamonds, tally marks, 39 dots. Made by punch & hammer (antler tip?)
  SR Style 5: Hundreds of fine scratched lines (chert flake/biface)
  SR Style 6: Deeply incised lines — female fertility ritual (Barrett 1952, Loeb 1926)
• Panel 2: 147 × 135 cm, moss-covered until rediscovery
  SR Style 1: Two large PCN petroglyphs (27×24 cm & 19×16 cm)
  SR Style 2: 36 cupules (2.5-5 cm, possibly early Holocene)
  SR Style 3: 6 grooved lines (largest 42 cm long)
Chronology: Styles 1-3 (oldest) → Style 4 → Style 5 → Style 6 (~350 BP to historic)
Some Style 4 elements appear re-pecked by historic Wailaki (1850-1900)
History: Discovered 1913 by O.W. Degen (NWP Railroad surveyor).
Degen wrote to Kroeber; material passed to Goddard (studying Wailaki).
Listed as Steward's PT.2 (1929). Lost 80 years — inaccurate location records.
Rediscovered Oct 1993 by CDF forester Dave Drennan during timber inspection.
Named for the Slakaiya tribelet (1 of 18 Wailaki groups, Goddard 1923)
Foster & Foster, in Wallace & Riddell eds., UC ARF No. 60

sketeclkascanan (Slakaiya Wailaki village)
"Mush throw away sunny place" — a large Slakaiya village downstream with a ceremonial rock. Mush-like substance on rock face each spring predicted the year's acorn crop. Named for Panther, who threw away mush here when tired from hunting. (Goddard 1923)

kaslenkyobi (Slakaiya Wailaki village)
"Spring large in" — a good rock shelter where a family wintered. Captain Jim, Goddard's informant, was forced to leave his father-in-law to die here when pursued by white men. (Goddard 1923)

kaitcdantadan (Slakaiya Wailaki village)
"Christmas berries place" — northernmost Slakaiya hamlet, near a bend in the Eel. Graveyard a quarter mile north. Northern boundary marked by tributary creek tciskot. (Goddard 1923)

tosekyok'at (Slakaiya Wailaki village)
A large Slakaiya village a quarter mile downstream from the boundary creek. (Goddard 1923)

Coleman Creek Petroglyphs (Eel River)
Discovered by a photographer on a river trip — previously unknown to archaeologists
"Many petroglyphs in a setting of beautiful meadows steeply sloping down to the Eel"
Visited 2012 by Jon Harman (DStretch) & Pierre Pelet (BARARA)
Not yet formally documented by Dan Foster (Senior State Archaeologist, ret. 2012)
Accessible only by river — remote Eel River canyon
Wailaki territory

Spyrock Station Petroglyphs
Distinct from Spyrock Road (CA-MEN-1912), ~10 miles downstream
Located on the Eel River near the former Spyrock railroad station
Contains many SR Style 4 pecked abstract designs:
wavy lines, linked circles, zigzags, abstract figures, AND dozens of cupules
Cupules superimposed over pecked elements — key to regional chronology
(Proves cupules younger than Style 4 at this site; confirmed by repatination differences)
Photo by Robert Connick (1960); Paul Freeman (BARARA) source
Foster & Foster use this site to establish the style sequence across the region

Keystone Petroglyphs (CA-MEN-2200)
Central Mendocino County, between Willits and Ukiah
Contains concentric-circle motifs (among oldest styles in region)
Concentric circles, cupules, shields with superimposed incised lines
Gary & McLear-Gary (1988) proposed a chronological sequence here:
1) abstract curvilinear/grids 2) concentric circles 3) incised lines
Consistent with the sequence at Slakaiya Rock
Pomo territory — one of 178 sites in Pomo/Yuki/Coast Miwok lands

Feliz Creek Petroglyphs (CA-MEN-793)
Near Ukiah, Mendocino County
Concentric circles and deeply incised lines
Part of the 178+ petroglyph sites documented in Pomo/Yuki/Coast Miwok territory
Pomo territory — southern end of the Eel River rock art corridor

Elledge Valley Baby Rock #2
Near Ukiah, Mendocino County
PCN/cupule site — part of the "Baby Rocks" tradition
Hedges (1983a) noted: deeply incised lines always present,
but at this site only a single cupule — suggesting incised lines
more strongly linked to fertility rituals than cupules themselves
Pomo territory

Potter Valley Project — Eel River Captured (1908)
Scott Dam (1922) created Lake Pillsbury, blocking uppermost Eel River
Cape Horn Dam diverts water through 1-mile tunnel to Russian River
Blocked fish passage to ~10% of watershed for 100+ years
Hope: PG&E surrendering license (2023); demolition possible ~2028
When dams come down, the Eel becomes the longest free-flowing river in California
Huchnom homeland — diverted their river to another watershed entirely

Nome Cult Farm → Round Valley Reservation (1856-present)
Yuki homeland transformed into a concentration point for 6+ displaced tribes
Settlers took the southern half of the valley; govt crammed tribes into the north
Multiple tribes "driven like cattle" — elderly and sick died en route
High picket fences corralled captives
Ghost village Amacha: built for 100, "one day soldiers took all the people and burned the houses"
The Yuki — the valley's original people — became a minority in their own homeland

Lost Redwood Forests — Sinkyone/Coast Yuki Territory
Entire South Fork Eel / Sinkyone coast clearcut from 1850s onward
Old-growth coast redwoods reduced to 5% of original extent statewide
Loss of redwoods = loss of entire subsistence ecosystem:
salmon streams, basket materials (sedge, willow), food plants, shelter
Sinkyone Council working to restore: 4,531+ acres now under tribal stewardship

1964 Christmas Flood — Eel River Devastation
>500,000 cubic feet per second — record for 20th century
Warm Pineapple Express rains melted snowpack
Destroyed towns, ancient redwoods, highways, railroad
Washed away much of Weott, stranded hundreds in Eel River Canyon
Exacerbated by clearcut logging — increased runoff and sediment
The river itself became a weapon of destruction

Round Valley Indian Reservation (Covelo)
~44 sq mi (26,000+ acres). Confederation: Yuki, Wailaki, Concow, Little Lake Pomo, Nomlaki, Pit River. Enrollment: 5,781 (2022); ~21% on-reservation. First CA forest carbon offset (2015). Yuki & Wailaki taught at grade school. The Yuki — the only CA tribe to continuously live on their ancestral homeland.

Cahto Indian Tribe — Laytonville Rancheria
~264 acres, ~3 mi west of Laytonville. Cahto and Pomo peoples. Operates Red Fox Casino. Tribal police, housing authority, EPA office. Pre-contact Cahto: 500-1,100.

InterTribal Sinkyone Wilderness Council
Not a rancheria — a 10-tribe land trust & conservation consortium. Founded 1986. 4,531+ acres under protection. Members: Cahto, Pinoleville Pomo, Round Valley, Sherwood Valley, Coyote Valley, Scotts Valley, Hopland, Redwood Valley, Robinson, Manchester-Pt Arena. First-ever InterTribal Protected Area (1997).

Sherwood Valley Rancheria of Pomo Indians
Near Willits, Mendocino County. Pomo people. Vice-chair Buffie Schmidt spoke at Tc'ih-Léh-Dûñ ceremony 2022.
